_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following paragraphs are reproduced from the Los Angeles County Department of Public Works - Site #13 RMPSubmit Executive Summary.



Los Angeles County Department of Public Works, Site 13 is located at the following coordinates: 34.612419 (latitude) and -118.130689 (longitude). Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has developed a risk management program to address the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785). Los Angeles County Department of Public Works is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Los Angeles County Department of Public Works staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using chlorine. 





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training, reputable contractors, and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Chlorination Disinfection Process. Los Angeles County Department of Public Works policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

This Los Angeles Department of Public Works facility uses chlorine and accompanying equipment for water treatment. Although chlorine is toxic at high levels, the concentrations used in disinfecting drinking water are low enough not to pose any risks to human health. 



Liquid chlorine is delivered to the facility in a one-ton container. The one-ton container is transferred to the Chlorine ChlorTainer area by a trolley monorail system. The connected chlorine container is within a ChlorTainer containment vess

el. The container is connected by a yoke and adapter with new lead gaskets within the ChlorTainer. Chlorine gas under pressure flows from the online container through a vacuum regulator that is directly connected to each ChlorTainer. The vacuum regulator reduces the chlorine pressure to a vacuum. The chlorine gas is suctioned out of the container using vacuum pressure generated by a flow of pumped water. No chlorine piping or tubing is under pressure outside the ChlorTainer. One gaseous chlorinator is installed adjacent to the ChlorTainer. The chlorinator meters and injects gaseous chlorine into the raw water supply as it enters the Water Distribution pipeline. Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. Chlorine leak detection and warning is provided by an immediate visual detection system. Special paint is applied near possible leak areas that turns from golden yellow to red when gas with a pH of 3 or less is present.





HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined for each covered process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment report, which is included as part of the CalARP 5 Year Update documentation.  



Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Scenario Description: One alternative case release scenario was modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment, which is included as part of the CalARP 5 Year Update documentation.  





RISK CONSIDERATIONS

Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the worst-case release scenario can potentially reach the community, Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices

of the company and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a release of a regulated substance:

?    The system has alarms and interlocks

?    The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

?    Gas detection is in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs.

?    The container is located within a locked secondary containment vessel.  The vessel is tamper proof and in the event of a release, would contain the contents of the chlorine preventing a release to atmosphere.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Los Angeles County Department of Public Works to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed; this includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Contractors





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no chlorine releases within the last five years.  

 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has filed a Unified Contingency Pl

an with Los Angeles County Fire Department and this plan includes:

?    Emergency Alarm Procedures

?    Evacuation Procedures

?    Safety and Health Considerations

?    Notification Procedures





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Seismic Assessment have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the reports.  





FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at the Los Angeles County Department of Public Works Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 





FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

The use of flammable materials at the Los Angeles County Department of Public Works Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.





EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7(q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of chlorine were addressed by the PHA and Seismic Assessment.  A test startup was performed with the contractor and personnel from Los Angeles County Department of Public Works in June 2008.  Furthermore, the well site is inspected by plant personnel several times a week.
